class_notes:
Students need to understand the definition of disease surveillance. Disease surveillance is defined as the systematic and ongoing data collection, analysis, and interpretation of outcome-specific data for use in the planning, implementation, and the timely dissemination of these data for prevention and control activities of diseases. This course is focused on surveillance of selected occupational diseases (occupational cancer, asthma, silicosis, malignant mesothelioma, tuberculosis) and COVID-19.
Students can expect to learn this course as follows.
¿	Learn about historical development of the concept of disease surveillance, purposes and uses of disease surveillance in public health practice. 
¿	Learn about surveillance of selected occupational diseases including occupational cancer, occupational asthma, silicosis, malignant mesothelioma, tuberculosis, and COVID-19 that affect morbidity and mortality in the United States.
¿	Learn about CDC occupational disease surveillance system available in the United States and prevention strategies using surveillance information on occupational diseases.
¿	Learn how to interpret disease surveillance data (morbidity and mortality) to track trends over time using existing CDC occupational disease surveillance data.
¿	Learn how to review and critique published articles relevant occupational diseases surveillance and write a report that summarizes the findings of a particular article and then present your review in class.
